review.title: Cost-Optimal Learning of Causal Graphs
review.abstract: We consider the problem of learning a causal graph over a set of variables with interventions. We study the cost-optimal causal graph learning problem: For a given skeleton (undirected version of the causal graph), design the set of interventions with minimum total cost, that can uniquely identify any causal graph with the given skeleton. We show that this problem is solvable in polynomial time. Later, we consider the case when the number of interventions is limited. For this case, we provide polynomial time algorithms when the skeleton is a tree or a clique tree. For a general chordal skeleton, we develop an efficient greedy algorithm, which can be improved when the causal graph skeleton is an interval graph.

sections.heading: 1 Introduction
sections.text: The problem is that imposing randomization to different variables in a causal inference problem can have significant and different costs. We follow the structural equation that models the framework [21, 29] and use interventions, i.e. we perform each intervention by formulating a causal diagram in which the interventions take place. To perform each intervention, we randomize a number of variables and collect new data from the performative system. We assume that the scientist wants to observe the causal effect of variable smoking on variable cancer.

sections.text: In this section we consider the cost-optimal intervention design problem for a given number of experiments. We construct a linear integer program formulation of this problem and identify the conditions under which it can be efficiently solved. sections.heading: 6.1 Coloring formulation of Cost-Optimum Intervention Design
sections.text: A common approach to solving combinatorial optimization problems is to write them as linear holistic programs: to solve the costs, binary variables with a linear objective function and a series of linear constraints are often used. Constraints determine the amount of realizable points. A convex object (a convex polytopic) can be constructed on the basis of a series of realizable points simply by taking their convex optimization problems, which cannot always be efficiently described. If possible, the linear program can be efficiently solved via this convex object, and the result is the optimal solution to the original combinatorial optimization problem. We develop an integral linear program formulation to determine the cost-optimal intervention design using its connection to correct graphs.
